title: AI / Open Q & A with Coach Keith

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's get started and see what topics and questions people have. This session is pretty informal since it's the end of the week. We'll do this for a bit, and if we run out of questions, I'll do some coding or something like that.

chapters.title: Discussion on AI Agents and Tooling Challenges

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I've taken an interest in AI agents and noticed many no-code tools to create and modify workflows. I'm starting to develop a vocabulary and hope to speak more intelligently over time.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: It definitely takes time to learn. Even for agentic projects I've done, I usually don't use specialized tools. If good tools exist to make development more reliable, that's great. But when learning, you can get pretty far without complex tooling. Focusing too much on tooling can be challenging because you have to learn both the concept and the tool. When I was learning ML and AI, I started from scratch with not the best code, but it helped me understand the ideas.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: One challenge in AI is that there are many tools, and everyone thinks they've found the best one. Almost all tools have flaws or are built for specific purposes but claim to solve bigger problems. If you don't know what a tool was built for, it's tough to use effectively. They promote positives but often don't reveal problems. Still, it's phenomenal what can be done.

chapters.title: Experiences with Web Scraping and Source Verification

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I saw a browser extension that scraped internet content, formatted it beautifully, and provided source information. It seemed magical, scraping entire sites and presenting data well.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That sounds like a glimpse of the future. It's good to occasionally double-check sources because citations can sometimes be incorrect or mismatched. Many AI systems start with high-quality builds that cost a lot, but once they gain users, they focus on reducing costs, often sacrificing some quality. It's important to keep an eye on that as systems become widely adopted.

chapters.title: Opinions on Data Annotation and AI Training

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I came across data annotation services that hire experts to review data, which becomes the 'truth' of the dataset. Have you done this or have opinions on it?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I haven't done data annotation myself, but I help companies find people with various expertise for that space. High-quality data produced by humans is critical for AI and ML. Large language models can generate data but it needs grounding in reality. Annotation involves correctness and usability since systems are used by people and need to generate revenue. I've worked on setting up annotation tasks, ensuring data quality, spot checking, and adjusting annotations to fix system issues. With LLMs, you need less data overall but more specialized data for complex tasks like math proofs or physics research.

chapters.title: Discussion on AI Content Copyright and Legal Issues

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Anthropic recently paid $1.5 billion to settle content copyright issues, likely involving book authors. It's good that content creators are sharing in the wealth, but the settlement didn't go through a verdict, so it won't set a legal precedent. I wish it had gone through courts to establish clearer rules.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: People stealing content runs contrary to our justice system. Ethical issues need to be negotiated to maintain our system; otherwise, society risks corruption. The US is valued for its strong justice system, and we shouldn't throw that away.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I agree. The case involves AI built from downloaded books by companies like Anthropic, OpenAI, and Facebook. Some methods, like scanning purchased books, are clever but legally unclear. Facebook's approach using torrents is clearly illegal. The legal debate is interesting because earlier models couldn't reproduce text verbatim, but now they can paraphrase or regurgitate content. I want to see courts define fairness and copyright in this context.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Academia understands acceptable use, like citing small parts of research with credit. AI models sometimes cite sources in responses, but not the original training data sources, which can be billions of sites. Citation is a good practice, but the question remains what counts as acceptable use in AI training.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Exactly. The law needs to catch up and clarify what counts as fair use or derivative work. The New York Times case alleges OpenAI regurgitates entire articles, bypassing paywalls and harming revenue. Whether that's true is unclear, but it's a small minority of use. The bigger issue is negotiating revenue flow between content providers and AI firms and tracking individual uses, which current technology can't do well. This creates a gap that needs addressing.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Attribution is easier with search-based AI that cites sources, but payment is complicated. How do you pay individual web content creators, especially small ones without legal representation? Big companies can enforce copyrights, but individuals get overlooked.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's a big concern. Small creators often get run over without lawyers. I hope future systems can be equitable to both big and small content providers. It's an ongoing challenge.

chapters.title: History and Evolution of Language Modeling and Fair Use

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I've worked in language modeling since around 2003-2004. Early models were simple autocomplete systems trained on web crawls. Back then, fair use was generally accepted for training because models didn't regurgitate full content. Now models memorize and paraphrase content, raising new legal questions. We need clearer laws defining fair use and derivative works in AI. The use case matters too; for example, New York Times claims OpenAI outputs entire articles, which harms revenue. The law and technology need to evolve to address these issues.

chapters.title: Student Introduction and Interest in Neural Networks

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: This is my first time here. I'm in advanced problem solving and working on project five, hoping to finish it soon. I noticed that classes, objects, and methods are the foundation of AI. I have a book called 'Make Your Own Neural Network' by Tariq Rasheed that teaches building neural networks with Python. I have many questions but the first is whether recognizing handwritten digits is something an advanced problem-solving programmer can do, or if it requires more advanced knowledge like machine learning.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: If you're comfortable with programming and math, you can definitely try a project like that. Those are the two main things you need. If you have a free weekend, it's worth a shot.

chapters.title: Organizing AI Learning and Course Modules

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is it possible to include a basic AI module in the course, like in Joy of Coding, so people don't have to rely on random books? Is there an organized way to learn this?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's something I need to learn more about regarding Joy of Coding modules. I started with an overview of all the skills needed for ML and AI, but it was overwhelming. Character recognition, like handwritten digits, is a classic starter example. It helps people understand the difference between numbers as characters and images, and what images mean in a computer and Python.

chapters.title: Explanation of Image Representation and Neural Network Basics

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: An image in a computer is usually represented as pixels, each with red, green, and blue values determining color and brightness. File formats like JPEG or PNG compress this data to save space. For a starter example like digit recognition, images are often fixed size and simplified to black and white to make neural network processing easier.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I find it fascinating that we can use classes and objects to build AI.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, AI programming uses all programming concepts like classes, objects, functions, and variables to organize code for understanding, updating, and debugging. These concepts apply equally in AI to make code manageable.

chapters.title: Clarifying AI Concepts and Starting a Neural Network Project

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: If I create a class and an object, what makes it AI? Is it the methods the object has?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Nowadays, AI usually refers to large language models accessed via API calls, but for digit recognition, your computer is sufficient. Digit recognition falls under machine learning, a subset of AI. The key is having code that can independently recognize patterns, like digits.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: What makes the object able to recognize a number from a picture? Is it the methods?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's look at some pseudocode to ground this. The AI part is in how the methods process input images to predict digits.

chapters.title: Basic Neural Network Structure and Image Processing

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Let's define a class called DigitClassifier. An image can be represented as a list of lists of floats, for example, a 10 by 10 grid. Each pixel has a value representing brightness. We can write a predict method that takes such an image as input.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Is the image referenced by rows and columns in the methods?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Yes, typically images are grids with x and y axes. The top-left corner is usually (0,0). We multiply each pixel value by a weight and sum them up to get an activation value. If the activation exceeds a threshold, we classify the digit accordingly.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Do you have to tell the program what a number one looks like?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: That's the challenge. You can hardcode weights, but that requires many if statements. Instead, machine learning trains the model by giving it many examples of digits, letting it learn the weights that best recognize each digit.

chapters.title: Machine Learning Training and Pattern Recognition

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Machine learning is about adjusting weights based on training data so the model predicts digits correctly more often. The model learns patterns for each digit from many images. The training process finds the best weights for each pixel coordinate to match the digit patterns.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: So the model codifies patterns into coordinates with associated numbers?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Exactly. For images, these are pixel coordinates and weights. For other data types, the representation differs.

chapters.title: Understanding Neural Networks and AI Terminology

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I'm interested in the simplest AI or neural network I can build with Python.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Whether you call it AI or neural network, it's a big category. Neural networks transform images mathematically to categorize digits. There are other methods too, like decision trees, but for images, neural networks are effective because writing many if statements is impractical.

chapters.title: Challenges and Expectations in Machine Learning

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: Machine learning models rarely work perfectly 100% of the time. They have error rates, especially with ambiguous inputs like similar digits or unusual handwriting. Testing should be done across various scenarios to understand performance.

chapters.title: Planning a Group Neural Network Project

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I want to try building a neural network after finishing advanced problem solving and the technical interview. Is there a place or group for this kind of project?

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: This session is a great place for that. If enough people are interested, we can organize group sessions or tutorials. We might use online tutorials for MNIST and Python and create a GitHub repository as a central place for collaboration. It won't happen immediately but is a good future goal.

segments.speaker: Other
segments.text: Keith has limited time, so it's important for participants to do homework and research before asking questions. This respects his time and helps avoid basic questions. Group discussions before consulting Keith would be beneficial.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: I agree. Setting boundaries on what the group wants to learn and breaking topics into steps with homework is a good approach. This session and Discord are good places for questions and collaboration.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: Thanks for the presentation and time. I'll be popping in periodically and look forward to exploring neural networks further.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: You're welcome. Once you get through foundational material and gather a group interested in neural networks, reach out and we can plan next steps. This session and Discord are good places for ongoing support.

segments.speaker: Student
segments.text: I should get started on dinner now. Thanks again. See you all.

segments.speaker: Host
segments.text: See you. Take care.

processing_notes: Removed filler words and speech disfluencies for clarity.
Corrected technical terminology and clarified references.
Identified speakers as Host and Student based on context.
Segmented transcript into chapters by topic and conversation flow.
Maintained chronological order and preserved speaker intent and tone.
